If you believe that your employer is just being cheap and undervaluing your contributions, then standing your ground and negotiating for what you're worth may be the right decision for you, even if it comes with the risk of potential job loss. 

Here are some tips on how to navigate this situation:

1. Do your research: Make sure you have done your research on salary ranges for your position and industry. Be prepared with examples and facts to support why you should be paid higher.

2. Focus on your value: In the negotiation, focus on the value that you bring to the company and the positive impact you have made on the organization. Use concrete examples to demonstrate your contributions.

3. Remain professional: Remember to remain professional and polite throughout the negotiation process.

4. Be prepared to walk away: If your employer is unwilling to offer even a fair salary or non-monetary benefits, you may need to be prepared to walk away. Start looking for other job opportunities and weigh the risks and benefits of leaving.

Ultimately, it is up to you to decide if it's worth it to stand your ground and negotiate for a fair salary or if you're willing to continue being underpaid. Remember to take time to weigh your options and to make the best decision for your long-term career growth and financial well-being.
